components.description:
A board which contains the scene name, number, and film. A person ‚Äòclaps‚Äô the board shut at the top while saying ‚ÄúAction‚Äù or ‚ÄúCut‚Äù to indicate the start and stop of a scene that is being filmed.

This is used to synchronise the audio of the clap with the visuals.

version.description:
Released in October 2010, Unicode 6.0 was the first version of the Unicode Standard to support emoji.

Some characters in prior versions of Unicode were retroactively updated to provide an emoji presentation. This release was the first to introduce new characters for the sole purpose of compatability with emojis being used in Japan.

emoji_net_data.category: Miscellaneous Symbols And Pictographs -> Entertainment symbols

bn:00088192v: Make a film or photograph of something

bn:00034471n: Film, movie, or motion picture, is a series of still images on a strip of plastic which, when run through a projector and shown on a screen, creates the illusion of moving images.
A form of entertainment that enacts a story by sound and a sequence of images giving the illusion of continuous movement
A series of still images which, when shown on a screen, creates the illusion of moving image
A film, also called a movie or motion picture, is a series of still images which, when shown on a screen, creates the illusion of moving images due to the phi phenomenon.
Sequence of images that give the impression of movement

bn:00019441n: A clapperboard is a device used in filmmaking and video production to assist in the synchronizing of picture and sound, and to designate and mark particular scenes and takes recorded during a production.

A clapper board; a device used in film production, having hinged boards that are brought together with a clap, used to synchronize picture and sound at the start of each take of a motion picture or other video production.
A white and black striped board used in movie making

A device used in film production, having hinged boards that are brought together with a clap, used to synchronize picture and sound at the start of each take of a motion picture or other video production.
Photographic equipment used to synchronize sound and motion picture; boards held in front of a movie camera are banged together
